etymologies: mid 18th century. From post-classical Latin profert

definitions: In early use: the production or exhibition of a deed in a court of law; (subsequently) a formal allegation that a deed is produced in court. Especially in "to make profert of": to produce or allege the production of (a document, deed, etc.) in court.

notes.text: By the mid 19th century, and perhaps for several centuries before this, it was by agreement normally no longer necessary to produce the physical document in court, but only to allege that it had been produced.
